Merge pull request #1224 from abriosi/patch-1

Edit `guardInterval` description

Edit `guardInterval` description

When running multiple concurrent workers with delayed tasks, the default value of `guardInterval` will cause spikes on network bandwidth, cpu usage and memory usage. Each concurrent worker will run the delayed job watchdog. In case of multiple workers set this value to something much higher, e.g. `guardInterval = numberOfWorkers*5000`

Merge pull request #862 from mxstbr/prettier

Implement prettier

Run prettier in CI

This enforces that folks don't skip the precommit hook and commit wrong
styling by failing the CI if contributors explicitly disable the
precommmit hook somehow.

Disable stylistic eslint rules

Now that `prettier` automatically manages the style of the code for us
there's no reason to throw errors while linting, since `prettier` will
take care of it anyway.
Run prettier once over all JavaScript files'

Set up prettier as a pre-commit hook

This uses `lint-staged` together with `husky` to run `prettier` on
commit to format all staged files to the consistent code style.

Merge pull request #860 from mxstbr/default-job-options

Add defaultJobOptions to Queue
Add test for removeOnFail in defaultJobOptions

Add defaultJobOptions to Queue

I'd like to pass `removeOnComplete` and `removeOnFail` only once,
instead of every time I run `.add()` on a queue. This patch adds a new
option to queues called `defaultJobOptions` which, as the name suggests,
sets the default job options.

Also adds two tests verifying that the option is passed through
correctly and that it works with `removeOnComplete`. I wasn't sure
whether to more tests were necessary, if so, please just let me know and
I'll work on it.

Merge pull request #513 from bradvogel/patch-3

Readme tweaks

Change default lock timeout to 30sec. It's a more sensible default for the following reasons:
* A lot of people complain about jobs being double processed currently. So there must be a lot of poorly written job processor code out there that stalls the event loop :). Or folks, like me, forget that we're running our code on tiny instances in the cloud where the CPU is so limited that a tiny bit of JS work will max the CPU. A 30sec timeout would give a bit more buffer. At least until we figure out a generic solution like #488.
* An expired lock (due to event loop stalling) is quite fatal now that we check the lock prior to moving the job to the completed or failed (previously we would still move it if there wasn't a lock). So if a long running job (let's say 2min) stalls the event loop for even just 5sec, it means that the job can never complete at that point. It might still continue processing, but another worker would have likely picked it up as a stalled job and processed it again. Or if it doesn't happen to get picked up as stalled, when it finally completes it still won't be moved to completed because it lost the lock at one time.
* The tradeoff is that it will take longer for jobs to be considered 'stalled'. So instead waiting max 5sec to find out if a job was stalled, we'd wait max 30sec. I think this is generally OK and that most people aren't running jobs that are that time-sensitive. Actual stalled jobs [due to process crashes] should be extremely rare anyways.

This also sets the stalledInterval to 30sec since it doesn't do much good to have it run more frequently than the lock timeout. It's also slightly expensive to run in Redis as it iterates all jobs in the 'active' queue (see moveUnlockedJobsToWait.lua), so it'd be nice to run this less often anyways.

Fix for max 24 day delay issue #244

Prevent race condition that forces code to block and wait until LOCK_RENEW_TIME

Simplify fix for max-timeout-issue

Revert back to use of MAX_VALUE but add a gate to prevent setTimeout trigger with number larger than max 32bit int.

Fix for #244

The implementation of setTimeout in Nodejs relies on a 32 bit integer for timeout values. The current default timeout in the delay timer is the max 64 bit integer which causes any possible delay values to start the delay timer. Delays longer than 2^31-1 ms (roughly 24 days) cause an integer overflow and the timeout triggers immediately.

This pull request replaces the default timeout with the max 32bit signed integer so that only valid ms values can start the timer. Anything longer than 24 days will be caught by the guardian timer.

To reproduce this issue clear anything in the delay set and create a new job with a delay > 2^31 ms. It will execute immediately.

Merge pull request #448 from josephwarrick/master

Some fixes regarding pausing locally
Use methods on the prototype instead of properties with a getter.
Don't declare reject variable in promises where we won't use it.

Increase timeout for test.

Since we finish waiting for new jobs before closing the queue, it
can take a little bit longer to close the queue than it did
previously, so this extends the time allowed for this test.

Only wait for one job at a time.

When waiting for a new job, we generally use a blocking redis
command, which means that no other redis commands will be executed
until the blocking command has completed.

If we try to execute any commands while the blcoking command is
active, ioredis will queue those commands and execute them after
the blocking command completes.

When we do `queue.process(n, function...`, we issue `n` blocking
commands to wait for new jobs, one for each job we wish to process.
But, since this is a blocking command, only the first is actualy
executed, and the rest are queued up to be executed later.

When we want to pause our queue, we need to wait for these blocking
commands to complete, otherwise we might end up processing a job
when we think the queue is paused.

If we queue all of the blocking commands up front, then it can take
a long time for them to all complete one at a time.

This changes the code to only issue one blocking command at a time,
and if there is already one pending, wait until it resolves before
issuing another blocking command.

This means that we can re-check the state of our queue more often,
and if we find that our queue is pausing, we can choose not to
issue the blocking command to wait for another job to process.

Consider jobs being retrieved when pausing queue locally.

It was possible for our queue to be "paused", but still be working
on jobs, because we were not considering jobs that were in the
process of being retrieved when the pause was initiated.

This ensures that our queue is not considered paused until we have
stopped listening for jobs to process, and until we have processed
all jobs that we might have retrieved after initiating the pause.

Add test to verify that queues wait for blocking job retrieval to
complete, and for any new jobs retrieved to complete, before
pausing the queue locally.

Only count locally processed jobs when locally pausing queue.

If we count how many jobs are active globally, and then wait for
that many jobs to complete locally, this promise will never be
resolved, because some other process might be working on some of
those active jobs that were counted.

Since we are really interested in how many jobs are in progress in
this particular process, we should use count of active local jobs,
rather than a count of all active jobs.

Add a test to verify that queues will pause locally when there are
multiple workers processing jobs from the queue.
stop the timmer a bit early to avoid a possible race condition

[fix test] handle stream write after close error
The bull Queue instance is an EventEmitter which emits errors bound to the error event of the stream.Writable ioredis client.  EventEmitters throw if the error event is not handled.  Bull is durable and will recover from lost writes by failing/retrying jobs where necessary.  Therefore the error can be safely ignored since this is a test case where we rapidly destroy queues.
The buffer waiting to be written to the stream is just a publish event for a waiting job:

Merge pull request #377 from mixmaxhq/fix-double-processing

Fixes double-processing issue described in https://github.com/Optimal
Remove unused parameter `renew` in `processJob`. This was removed in https://github.com/OptimalBits/bull/pull/359/files#diff-b68fbb0f945cdf9cddec65ddf0fbe456L561 and I forgot to clean it up.
Only ensure the job is in the active set the first time acquiring it. After that, we know we have the lock so we can be certain that someone else hasn't moved it.

When renewing the lock, ensure that we have it. In the case that double processing occurs (due to one process stalling and failing to renew the job lock in time), it will not steal the lock from the another process when it resumes processing.

At some point we still need to figure out how to handle the case where a lock fails to renew.
Increase number of jobs to make test more stressful. In my testing, 11 jobs was too few to reveal subtle race conditions.

Fixes double-processing issue described in https://github.com/OptimalBits/bull/issues/371#issuecomment-260158407.

Double-processing happens when two workers find out about the same job at the same time via `getNextJob`. One worker is taking the lock, processing the job, and moving it to completed before the second worker can even try to get the lock. When the second worker finally gets around to trying to get the lock, the job is already in the completed state. But it processes it anyways since it got the lock.

So the fix here is for the takeLock script to ensure the job is in the active queue prior to taking the lock. That will make sure jobs that are in wait, completed, or even removed from the queue altogether don't get double processed. Per the discussion in #370 though, takeLock is parameterized to only require the job be in active when taking the lock while processing the job. There are other cases such as job.remove() that the job might be in a different state, but we still want to be able to lock it.

This fixes existing existing broken unit test "should process each job once".

This also prevents hazard https://github.com/OptimalBits/bull/issues/370.

Merge pull request #361 from mixmaxhq/add-removeOnComplete

Add new 'removeOnComplete' option to atomically remove a job when it
Change process stalled jobs strategy to instead look for an unlocked job in the active queue on every cycle (looking at the oldest active jobs first).
Give script different name so it doesn't get cached with considering the removeOnComplete parameter.

Micro-optimization: Since we can assume there's only one job id in the active list, and that jobs being completed are likely near the end of the list, then we can stop iterating the list after finding the first element starting at the end.
Add new 'removeOnComplete' option to atomically remove a job when it is completed (useful for high-volume queues). Fixes https://github.com/OptimalBits/bull/issues/354
Only emit 'stalled' event if there were stalled jobs.

Rewrite the handling of process stalled jobs to be atomic so it doesn't double-process jobs. See https://github.com/OptimalBits/bull/issues/356 for more on how this can happen.

Additionally, this addresses long-standing issue where a job can be considered "stalled" even though it was just moved to active and before a lock could be obtained by the worker that moved it (https://github.com/OptimalBits/bull/issues/258), by waiting a grace period (with a default of LOCK_RENEW_TIME) before considering a job as possibly stalled. This gives the (real) worker time to acquire its lock after moving it to active.

Note that this includes a small API change: the 'stalled' event is now passed an array of events.

Merge pull request #151 from mosilla/safe-close

Ensure close() doesn't cause the application to hang
attempt to make the delayed/restart test less prone to failure

Fix failing tests

The previous implementation assumed that only one lockRenewer
timer is active at a time, but there can be several. The timer
manager has been updated to reflect this.

In addition, the delay timer is no longer managed by the timer
manager since it is persistent (its initial value is
Number.MAX_VALUE) and would never be cancelled. Instead,
it is closed immediately by close().

Ensure close() doesn't cause the application to hang.

Previously, calling close() could result in Redis connections
being closed before internal timers depending on those
connections have executed or been cancelled. This would cause
the application to hang indefinitely.

This commit renames the old close() method -> disconnect()
and adds a new close() implementation which wraps disconnect()
but defers the call until all outstanding timer handles have
been released.

This ensures that close() is safe to call from anywhere at
any time, even from within a job handler.
